data.title: GameTime.IsRunningSlowly always true
data.body:
Looks like GameTime.IsRunningSlowly will almost always be true for fixed timestep. How Microsoft describe the field is rather vague. Monogame is certainly upholding the letter of their wording on this page<sup>[1](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/microsoft.xna.framework.gametime.isrunningslowly.aspx)</sup>, but the field is all but useless in it's current implementation. The page on TargetElapsedTime<sup>[2](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/microsoft.xna.framework.game.targetelapsedtime.aspx)</sup> describes IsRunningSlowly slightly differently and makes it much more useful.

Currently if the (_accumulatedElapsedTime > TargetElapsedTime) check is true, it will claim the game is running slow. If we have a TargetElapsedTime of 0.1 seconds, and 0.100001 have passed, it claims we are running slow, while if 0.99999 seconds have elapsed we don't get an update() at all (we loop around RetryTick: till we do). Therefore the game is only running not-slow if (_accumulatedElapsedTime == TargetElapsedTime), which because of the variability in sleeping is almost never the case.

I propose that IsRunningSlowly is set to be true if we are doing more than 1 update per draw. Easiest way I can see is to make the current test (_accumulatedElapsedTime > (TargetElapsedTime + TargetElapsedTime), but there's probably a better wizard out there who can find a better solution than that.

data.title: Is there a reason why SpriteBatcher doesn't use a vertex/index buffer pair?
data.body:
When looking into performance issues in the JSIL MonoGame port, I noticed that SpriteBatcher is doing a lot of extra work for no obvious reason, and it's using DrawUserIndexedPrimitives to flush each batch instead of filling a single index/vertex buffer pair. Filling a single pair would mean that all the queued up drawing operations could be uploaded in one go instead of being uploaded in tiny chunks. For the browser this is really important because the cost of each OpenGL call is _dramatically_ increased due to WebGL's architecture, and a single DrawUserIndexedPrimitives call involves lots of OpenGL calls.

It seems to me like SpriteBatch could fill the actual index/vertex buffers (as arrays) in one go sequentially after it sorts the SpriteBatchItems, upload the full buffers, then render chunks of those buffers when it needs to flush batches. That would cut down on OpenGL calls considerably and I think it'd probably be faster in desktop OpenGL/Direct3D setups as well. Thoughts?

(mumble grumble spritebatch's design is SO bad for performance)

EDIT: For reference, the Platformer2D example seems to be drawing _six vertices at a time_, each draw operation involving the following high cost operations:

Applying all the rendering states (even worse, each DrawUserIndexedPrimitives flags the ib/vb as dirty, so each call to ApplyState is _forced_ to do work here)
Pinning the index/vertex buffers as GCHandles
Applying the current vertex declaration
Filling a temporary index buffer with provided indices
Filling a temporary vertex buffer with provided vertices
Calling vertexAttribPointer repeatedly to set up all the attribute streams

EDIT 2: This is no doubt responsible for some miserable performance on PSM as well. If memory serves, PSM does not like it when you do dozens to hundreds of uploads per frame, and state changes were more expensive there too.

data.title: Added new Kindle devices for inverted orientation
data.body:
Amazon released new Kindle devices that cause MonoGame games to run upside down.

To give some background on the issue, all kindles since the Kindle Fire HD report their landscape right and landscape left orientations opposite of standard Android devices. Info on this [here](https://forums.developer.amazon.com/forums/message.jspa?messageID=1606). I can't find the original docs by Amazon, but they recommended checking `Android.OS.Build.Model` and inverting your game...

Dean Ellis originally put in this fix based on some changes we used in Draw a Stickman: EPIC.

This is the updated list we are using now in [Battlepillars for Amazon](http://www.amazon.com/Hitcents-Battlepillars/dp/B00GGNF6Y0/ref=sr_1_1?s=mobile-apps&ie=UTF8&qid=1384193019&sr=1-1&keywords=battlepillars). Our app was just approved through their testing process:

data.title: Change clear colour for Intel performance.
data.body:
_THIS BREAKS XNA COMPATIBILITY!_

Modern (Sandybridge +) Intel Integrated Graphics chipsets have a fast clear/blit unit ('blorp') which, at least under Mesa, can only do fast color clears if all of the channels are being cleared to either full (1.0 or 255) or empty (0). The default XNA discard colour, CornflowerBlue, does not have this property. This patch changes the discard colour to black (0,0,0,255) as this is the colour likely to be best supported by hardware.

This patch gets rid of a per-clear performance warning on Intel Ivybride/Mesa 10.0 git using ARB_debug_output.

I perfectly understand if you guys don't want to break the spec, but I thought I'd put this out there anyway.

data.title: Cache whether or not a VBO is bound when using GL
data.body:
Reduces number of redundant glBindBuffer() calls when using DrawUser*Primitives several times in a row.

Basically, at the moment, every DrawUser_Primatives call (with the GL backend) starts by calling glBindBuffer() a couple of times to bind the null buffer as both a vertex and element (index) buffer. This patch basically caches whether or not the last draw operation was from a User pointer, and so the glBindBuffer calls only happen on the first DrawUser_Primatives call after a non-user-pointer call.

The actual performance improvement here is pretty small, but it sure makes digging through traces in apitrace more pleasent.

NB: It would be possible to cache whether or not vertex and index buffers are bound separately, but I doubt it's worth it.

 David

data.title: PssTexture2D Not being disposed by Texture2D
data.body:
For Playstation Mobile, Texture2D maintains an internal PssTexture2D to handle all the Magic. It turns out that this resource is not being disposed, leaving the memory hanging around should Dispose be called.

To test this, Simply load a Texture2D, Dispose it (or Call Content.Unload if it's the only thing in there), and draw the image and observe that it is drawn.

I was able to resolve this locally by adding the following to Texture2D.cs:

protected override void Dispose (bool disposing)
{
# if PSM

```
   _texture2D.Dispose();
```
# endif

```
   base.Dispose (disposing);
```

}
